content.title: Cervical Rib
content.definition: A supernumerary rib arising from the C7 vertebra, present in 0.5-1% of the population, which may contribute to thoracic outlet syndrome by narrowing the thoracic outlet.

clinical_features.complete: Fully formed rib articulating with first rib or sternum
clinical_features.incomplete: Partial rib with fibrous band to first rib
clinical_features.fibrous_band: Fibrous band only without bony rib
clinical_features.bilateral: Present on both sides in ~50% of cases

clinical_features.neurogenic_tos: Most common TOS type associated with cervical rib
clinical_features.venous_tos: Less commonly associated with venous TOS

clinical_features.ct: CT for bony detail and relationship to vessels
clinical_features.mri: MRI for soft tissue and fibrous bands

clinical_features.resection: Complete resection of rib and fibrous bands
clinical_features.first_rib: Often combined with first rib resection

clinical_features.symptomatic: Only 5-10% of those with cervical ribs develop TOS

content.statement: Cervical Rib is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Rare-Syndromes that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Cervical Rib helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Cervical Rib include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Cervical Rib.

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
